data.title: Bunker Bean (1936)
data.meta_description: A shy office worker becomes a hero when a fortune teller calls him another Napoleon.
data.text:
For as interesting as this gets towards the end, this didn't really seem to earn that, rather like they had the ideas for that first and then the rest got filled in quickly to get things done. Until the fairly interesting ending, this mostly seems to get by on a couple more interesting supporting characters, like Jessie Ralph as the grandmother (and the best character in this). In contrast, even when Owen Davis Jr. seems to get more assertive, he doesn't really get much else going for him, really.

I give the "spite my father" marriage six months, tops.

lucy started workin in hollywood in 1933 and made her last movie in 1974, shit… this is based on a book by harry wilson, this had already been adapted to movies twice during the silent era. This rko version is the first sound version.

lucy got into showbiz early, performing as a teen on stage in jamestown NY. At 15 she convinced mom to enroll her in a dramatic school in nyc, she was classmates with an 18 year old bette davis. the school apparently didn’t see the star in lucy, they wrote her mom, dede(?), a note saying “lucy’s wasting her time and ours.. she’s too shy and reticent to put her best foot forward”.

Lucy was under contract…
